content: The Act titled "Stop Adolescent Smoking Without Excessive Bureaucracy Act of 2008" aims to strengthen state laws regarding tobacco product sales to individuals under the age of 18. This includes setting a youth compliance target and enforcement measures. The Act "Stop Adolescent Smoking Without Excessive Bureaucracy Act of 2008" requires states to have laws prohibiting the sale of tobacco products to individuals under 18, and restricts minors from purchasing, receiving, or possessing tobacco products in public places. The Act "Stop Adolescent Smoking Without Excessive Bureaucracy Act of 2008" mandates that states must have laws prohibiting the sale of tobacco products to individuals under 18 and restrict minors from purchasing, receiving, or possessing tobacco products in public places. Law enforcement agencies are required to notify parents or guardians if a minor is found to have purchased or possessed tobacco products in public. Retailers must implement a program within 180 days to notify employees about the new law. The Act mandates that retailers must implement a program to notify employees about state laws prohibiting the sale of tobacco products to individuals under 18 and ensure compliance with the law. Employers are not in violation if they rely on proof of age. The Act requires retailers to inform employees about laws against selling tobacco to minors. Employers can avoid violations by verifying age or implementing a compliance program. Individuals breaking the law may face penalties and community service. Some states have delayed enforcement due to legislative sessions. The Act requires states to establish goals for reducing retailer violations of tobacco laws through annual inspections. Some states have delayed enforcement until fiscal year 2012. The Act mandates states to set targets for decreasing retailer violations of tobacco laws through yearly, unannounced inspections. The violation rate should not exceed specified percentages each fiscal year until 2020 and beyond. The Act requires states to enforce tobacco laws to reduce underage access to tobacco products. States must conduct annual random inspections to ensure compliance with the law, with violation rates decreasing annually until 2020 and beyond. The funding agreement for a grant under section 1921 requires the State to conduct annual random inspections to enforce tobacco laws and reduce underage access to tobacco products. The State must submit a report to the Secretary detailing their enforcement activities and success in meeting goals. The State must conduct annual random inspections to enforce tobacco laws and reduce underage access to tobacco products. They must also detail their enforcement strategies and success in meeting goals in a report to the Secretary. Individuals under 18 can be used in compliance testing with parental consent. The State must conduct annual random inspections to enforce tobacco laws and reduce underage access to tobacco products. Individuals under 18 can participate in compliance testing with parental consent and direct supervision by the State during inspections. State settlement proceeds must be used for health programs, tobacco control, cessation activities, or economic development in tobacco regions. Noncompliance by the State is addressed. The Secretary determines State compliance with tobacco laws and may reduce grant allotment if noncompliant. If the Secretary determines that a State is not in compliance with certain subsections, the allotment under section 1921 for the State will be reduced by a specific percentage for each fiscal year. The Secretary may reduce the allotment under section 1921 for a State by 10 percent if the State is not in compliance with certain subsections for the fiscal year, with varying percentages for different fiscal years. The Secretary may reduce the allotment under section 1921 for a State by 10 percent if the State is not in compliance with certain subsections for the fiscal year. Additionally, the Secretary shall provide assistance to States in establishing and implementing State laws described in subsection (a), including developing model legislative language and offering technical guidance. The Secretary will assist States in developing and implementing laws by providing model legislative language and technical guidance. The term 'first applicable fiscal year' is defined as fiscal year 2012 for certain States and fiscal year 2010 for others. The amendment will apply from the first applicable fiscal year onwards. The provisions of section 1926 of the Public Health Service Act will apply to fiscal years before the first applicable fiscal year. The term "first applicable fiscal year" is defined in subsection (g) of section 1926. SEC. 3. PUBLIC DISCLOSURE OF INGREDIENTS. The Federal Cigarette Labeling and Advertising Act is amended to make ingredient information accessible to the public online within 48 hours of submission to the Secretary.
